awd_titl_txt: CAREER:    Rational Points via Asymptotics and Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
A wide range of systems of interest in science and engineering can be modeled by systems of polynomial equations. Often, particularly in computer science and cyber security, important quantities can be described by the set of solutions to a system of polynomial equations with rational coefficients, in other words by an algebraic variety. This project is concerned with determining when such a system has a solution where all coordinates are rational numbers. For an arbitrary system of equations, it can be quite difficult to determine whether there exist any such rational solutions. This research project develops a new perspective on this problem using geometry and asymptotic behavior. The research in this proposal is complemented by educational and outreach activities, including workshops for mid-to-late career graduate students focusing on presentation skills and how these skills can be leveraged to develop and broaden one's research program. 

The research projects fall in two main directions. The first focuses on the change in behavior of rational points and obstructions as the base field varies. In this direction, the project pursues a direct connection between the existence of 0-cycles and rational points on geometrically rational surfaces and explores new asymptotic questions that will shed light on Colliot-Thélène's conjecture on 0-cycles. The second focuses on leveraging dominant rational maps emanating from a variety X to obtain information about the Brauer group, rational points, and 0-cycles of X.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on questions in arithmetic geometry, which, as the name suggests, sits at the interface of two fields: arithmetic (the study of whole numbers and fractions); and geometry (the study of curves, surfaces, and higher-dimensional shapes).  These distinct areas are brought together through the study of solutions to polynomial equations, i.e., the study of varieties.  

A guiding philosophy of this area is Geometry controls arithmetic. For example, since the geometry of the variety labeled 'elliptic curve' is more complicated than the one labeled 'conic' (seen by the increased `curviness' of the graph), the arithmetic properties of the variety on the right should also be more complicated.  This turns out to be true in two senses: the rational points (i.e., the solutions with all coordinates fractions) on the variety on the right are sparser than those on the left, and it is harder to characterize all the rational points on the variety on the right.

This philosophy provides a powerful perspective, but many mathematical questions need to be answered to make it precise.  Which aspects of the geometry are important for a given arithmetic property? When we try to understand finer arithmetic properties, do we need to delve deeper into the geometry? What are the limitations of this philosophy?

The work supported by this grant focused on understanding three different types of arithmetic properties and how geometry influenced them.  The project outcomes include:

  • Identifying exceptional algebraic solutions, named isolated points, on systems of equations that cut out curves, and determining that, in a tower of so-called modular curves, these isolated points cast a shadow that can be detected among the simpler curves in the tower;
  • Uncovering a simple relationship, with striking theoretic and algorithmic implications, between the degrees of the defining equations of a particular type of system (that of torsors under abelian varieties) and the orders of mysterious obstruction classes, called Brauer classes;
  • Revealing that a certain class of equations, intersections of quadrics, obtain solutions ``earlier than one expects'', thereby giving an unexpected generalization of a forty-year-old theorem.

In addition to these scientific works, the grant supported the PI's workshop "Communicating Mathematics Effectively". The workshop helped early career researchers in number theory and arithmetic geometry gain skills in communicating their technical results to a more general audience.  Materials from this workshop were used to develop a graduate course at UW and were used as the basis for an article that appeared in the Notices of the American Mathematical Society.
